block.p: National elections in East Germany have been moved forward from May to March 18. The Government and all the major political groups agreed to form a coalition Government until then.
National elections in East Germany have been moved forward from May to March 18. The Government and all the major political groups agreed to form a coalition Government until then.
National elections in East Germany have been moved forward from May to March 18. The Government and all the major political groups agreed to form a coalition Government until then.
Probable challenger to Helmut Kohl wins election victory
Thousands marched in Bucharest, shouting anti-Communist and anti-Government slogans and demanding the resignations of the ruling Council of National Salvation.
Soviet rule in Azerbaijan began to break down two years ago. By the time the Kremlin sent troops to prevent the republic's Communists from falling, there remained little Communist power to rescue.
Poland's Communist Party dissolved after party members decided to create a new democratic and left-of-center party, and a large group of dissident members broke off to form a rival party.

The transition toward free markets from the centrally planned Communism of Eastern Europe promises to be a slower and more divisive process than the shift from political oppression to political freedom.

Japan's Liberal Democratic Party, the troubled organization that has governed for 35 years, has appealed to 200 corporate executives to rally -with cash in hand - behind it in the crucial national elections.

China is ''curing'' homosexuals with electric shocks or herbs that induce vomiting. But while homosexuality in China remains shrouded in mystery, it is not greeted with the bitter hostility often found in the West.
A Philippine officer linked to coup attempt is arrested
A Kashmiri plan to secede from India and send thousands of supporters into the streets of Srinagar was foiled after leading Kashmiri militants were captured by Indian security forces, officials said.

Israel's resettlement of Soviet Jews in the occupied terrorities has raised a clamor from many parts of the Arab and Muslim world, reflecting fears that the exodus of emigres will displace Palestinians.
The Panama Canal's administrator, Fernando Manfredo, the first Panamanian to hold the job, said his country must find ways ''to keep the Canal efficient'' commercially.
The Vice President visited Panama, receiving a warm welcome from some Panamanians who thanked the U.S. for invading. He said the U.S. would remove troops within ''weeks rather than months.''
A sympathetic Pope visits some of West Africa's poorest
Johannesburg Journal: A glossy magazine for blacks
The personality of Richard Darman, the Bush Administration's budget director, overshadows the fact that political allies and enemies consider him one of the most influential budget directors ever.
The size of the military budget, the proposed cut in the capital gains tax and the Administration's opposition to a cut in the Social Security tax were defended by Mr. Darman.

Washington at Work: Japan's image in America is skewed by racism and unfair trade demands, says Shintaro Ishihara, who has come to Washington to brush up his nation's and his own image the American way: rubbing elbows with his enemies.
Ethics investigations in the Senate will force the proud and clubby body to deal in the coming sessions with the uncomfortable issues that haunted the House last year.
The technique of DNA fingerprinting promoted by the nation's top law-enforcement agency for identifying suspects is not reliable enough to be used in court, scientists say.

Initiation rituals for female gangs in Los Angeles, often similar but less violent than male ceremonies, have become an expected event for many girls in the inner city, where gangs offer an otherwise lacking social structure.
Discrimination at Boston's banks will be addressed by a group of banks tak-ing part in a $430 million program to narrow the wide racial disparity in mortgage lending.
George Washington's slaves were treated better than many historians imagined, say archaeologists who have unearthed relics from his Mount Vernon home.
News analysis: Pollution standards will be increasingly costly for oil companies in the wake of accidents like the huge spill from the Exxon Valdez in Alaska.
Apple official resigns, signaling a possible overhaul
New Market Journal: Seeds of Highlander Folk School grow

The crew of a Colombian jetliner that crashed on Long Island told regional air-traffic controllers that the plane was short of fuel, but the information was not passed on to local controllers who guided the plane's descent.
Malpractice in New York hospitals has been linked to thousands of deaths and tens of thousands of injuries, but few victims seek recourse in the courts, a study shows.
New York City's car fleet is being cut by more than 1,000 - saving $10 million - as part of Mayor David Dinkins's austerity program.
The constitutional right to beg, upheld by a Federal court Friday, relieves panhandlers' fear of police harassment - but little else, say the homeless and homeless advocates.
Group calls for $991 million to save faltering courts
Police officer shoots unarmed teen-ager in the back
A gay Episcopal priest has resigned as director of a ministry to homosexuals only a month after he was ordained because of comments he made questioning church-mandated celibacy and monogamy.

Affordable housing or open space? The issue is being raised by a developer who wants to build nearly 200 condominiums at Peach Lake in North Salem, N.Y., but the town's zoning, which he calls exclusionary, will not allow it.
Robert Riddell, former New York U.S.O. director
Tom Wicker: A man of character
Itamar Rabinovich: Is Syrian-Israeli detente possible?
George Gerharz: Wisconsin's Learnfare: A bust
